markups: ''Collection representing players' current resources of a certain type of game elements.''

Games where players have several different game elements of the same hand in their possession but not in actual play have <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style>. While some games have as winning conditions that players should have emptied these <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style>, others use them for temporary storage or for places to collect valuable collections.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Contract%20Bridge">Contract Bridge</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Whist">Whist</link></style> are all traditional <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Card%20Games">Card Games</link></style> that all use <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mahjong">Mahjong</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Scrabble">Scrabble</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tien%20Gow">Tien Gow</link></style> are similar examples of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tile-Based%20Games">Tile-Based Games</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bohnanza">Bohnanza</link></style> is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Card%20Games">Card Game</link></style> where the order of cards in a player's hand is important, as the players have to play the cards in a specific sequence. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/San%20Juan">San Juan</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style> make use of <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> not only as storages of possible actions for players but also as their money resource. Players draw new <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> for each turn in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/RoboRally">RoboRally</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominion">Dominion</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Thunderstone">Thunderstone</link></style> and can in the two latter influence the contents of future <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> by purchasing new cards.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Memoir%20'44">Memoir '44</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pandemic">Pandemic</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ticket%20to%20Ride">Ticket to Ride</link></style> are all examples of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> which make use of card <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlestar%20Galactica:%20The%20Board%20Game">Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game</link></style> does this as well, but has both <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> of skill cards to overcome challenges and (small) <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> of loyalty cards that determine winning conditions.

Examples of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Card%20Games">Card</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tile-Based%20Games">Tile-Based Games</link></style> that do not make use of <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/No%20Thanks!">No Thanks!</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Carcassonne">Carcassonne</link></style> respectively.

While <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> requires something to fill them with, <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> most commonly, the basic design questions when using <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> is their size, how they should be constructed, and whether game elements should be replenished when used (see the <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> patterns about the actions that can be provided by the elements in the <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style>). As the <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> used to create <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> typically come from <style="Link"><link="decks">Decks</link></style>, the use of <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> is often a way of affecting how <style="Link"><link="decks">Decks</link></style> are used in a game.

Having an initial set of elements that shrinks as gameplay progresses makes these elements into <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resources</link></style> while keeping <style="CurrentLink">Hand</style> sizes constant or letting them fluctuate requires the consideration of what game actions refill the hand. <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> are typically replenished directly after game elements have been removed from them as part of gameplay actions; <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Rummy">Rummy</link></style> shows an example where the replenishment is done before the actions. The new <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> can either be taken from <style="Link"><link="drawing-stacks">Drawing Stacks</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="discard-piles">Discard Piles</link></style>, in some games (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Rummy">Rummy</link></style> again) players can make a choice between both of these. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cartagena">Cartagena</link></style> provides an example when players need to perform an action with associated <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> (moving their pieces backwards on the game track) to receive new <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> to their <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style> uses <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> in <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> to represent Money besides possible actions, making the sizes of <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> in this game vary widely. Regardless of if <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> constantly decrease in size or can grow, they are usually <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style> by having a maximum number of elements that may constitute the <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> are typically constructed through <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> although this can be combined or replaced by <style="Link"><link="drafting">Drafting</link></style>. The <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> may be created before "actual" gameplay begins through (this is the case in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Contract%20Bridge">Contract Bridge</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Whist">Whist</link></style>) or during gameplay (e.g. in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlestar%20Galactica:%20The%20Board%20Game">Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go%20Fish">Go Fish</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Magic:%20The%20Gathering">Magic: The Gathering</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style>). Players of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dominion">Dominion</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Thunderstone">Thunderstone</link></style> draw entirely new <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> after each turn and can indirectly construct their future <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> by <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> in new <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> for their <style="Link"><link="drawing-stacks">Drawing Stacks</link></style> (some <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> in these two games further allow players to manipulate which <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> will be in their next <style="CurrentLink">Hand</style>). Where one draws <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> from quite naturally affects which <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> one can get. Most games use <style="Link"><link="drawing-stacks">Drawing Stacks</link></style> but some also allow <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> to be replenished from <style="Link"><link="discard-piles">Discard Piles</link></style> (sometimes as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Privileged%20Actions">Privileged Actions</link></style>).

Some specific gameplay actions become possible due to the use of <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> in a game. Collecting <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style> in often goals or winning conditions in games with <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> - this can be found in both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mahjong">Mahjong</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Texas%20Hold'em">Texas Hold'em</link></style> shows that the <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style> can be combinations of <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> and commonly shared resources. Another specific action is having the <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Ability</link></style> of being allowed to look at other players' <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> (e.g. Gaius Balter's one-time ability to look at another player's loyalty <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlestar%20Galactica:%20The%20Board%20Game">Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game</link></style>). In <style="Link"><link="collectible-card-games">Collectible Card Games</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> play to role of providing the actions possible for a player at any given moment.

<style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> typically give players a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> between several different actions, e.g. which element to place when doing <style="Link"><link="tile-laying">Tile-Laying</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bohnanza">Bohnanza</link></style> is a rare exception in that players must play the bean <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> of the game in the order they were taken (unless gotten rid of through <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>).

<style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> are <style="Link"><link="containers">Containers</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> that assign players <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> of these. The main reason for providing players with these <style="Link"><link="containers">Containers</link></style> is to let them have a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> which of the game elements to use and which to save for future actions. The sizes of <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> are often limited, making their contents into <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>. Since these represent <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Actions">Actions</link></style> in most cases, this also makes <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> represent a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style>. Since <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pre-Customized%20Decks">Pre-Customized Decks</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="deck-building">Deck Building</link></style> affect heavily what <style="Link"><link="drawing-stacks">Drawing Stacks</link></style> consist of, they also affect what <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> are possible to have.

Typically, <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> are secret to other players so games with <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> tend to have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Information">Asymmetric Information</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="secret-resources">Secret Resources</link></style>. Being able to deduce other players' <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style>, or being able to look at them through some <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Ability</link></style>, does in most cases offers strategic advantages and this makes <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> give players <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> goals.

<style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> can guarantee <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Gameplay%20Time">Limited Gameplay Time</link></style> and more <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> the longer the game has progress in games where the <style="CurrentLink">Hands</style> shrink constantly during gameplay (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Contract%20Bridge">Contract Bridge</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Whist">Whist</link></style>) due to their contents being <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resources</link></style>.
